trial_identification.studytitle: Impact of HIV and Its Treatment on Reverse Cholesterol Transport
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Impact of HIV Infection and Treatment With Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy on Reverse Cholesterol Transport

interventions.interventions:
1 - No antiretroviral therapy for 12 months
2 - Initiating ARV therapy with an NNRTI based regimen
3 - Initiating ARV therapy with a PI based regimen

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- Male patients with HIV infection (3 groups of 50 patients each)
- HIV infected patients, na誰ve to ARV therapy and not likely to need to commence therapy for the duration of follow-up (12 months)
- HIV-infected patients, PI na誰ve, initiating therapy with PI-containing HAART (ARV na誰ve or NNRTI experienced changing to PI regimen)
- HIV-infected patients na誰ve to ARV therapy, initiating NNRTI-containing regimen
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
Exclusion criteria
- Treatment with any form of lipid lowering drugs, including fish oils.
- Body Mass Index greater than 27.

recruitment.hospital: Alfred Hospital and Baker Heart Research Institute - Melbourne

othercollaborator.othercollaboratorname: National Health and Medical Research Council, Australia

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To investigate the effect of treatment of HIV infection with highly active antiretroviral therapy on individual steps of reverse cholesterol transport, endothelial function and intima-media thickness in HIV patients.

contact.name: Dmitri Sviridov, Dr
contact.address: Baker Heart Research Institute, Commercial Road, Melbourne
